data.title: Text is super blurry now
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.0 (e52fb0bc87e6f5c8f144e172639891d8d8c9aa55, 2016-10-10T18:37:40.189Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: abusaidm.html-snippets-0.0.16, cssho.vscode-svgviewer-1.2.0, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.7, donjayamanne.python-0.4.0, DotJoshJohnson.xml-1.6.0, hnw.vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview-0.0.3, HookyQR.beautify-0.4.0, Ionide.Ionide-fsharp-2.6.9, lukehoban.Go-0.6.43, mohsen1.prettify-json-0.0.3, ms-vscode.cpptools-0.9.2, ms-vscode.csharp-1.4.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Update to 1.6
2. Reopen

Text has never been as crisp as Sublime, but now it's super blurry, from the menus on top to text in the workspace. At some point, you really ought to show some MS-pride and use DirectWrite since it's your tech and it's how Sublime achieves the crispest text of all editors. Something specific broke in 1.6, but I'm just mentioning DirectWrite as a long-term play.

Display is 1080p 24" with Skylake HD 530 graphics. This model: http://www.dell.com/support/home/us/en/19/product-support/servicetag/F111B22/diagnose

data.title: Syntax highlighting html tag incorrectly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an HTML file in VSCode
2. Note (or add) any HTML custom tags (i.e. in Angular projects) that use dashes in the tag name. For example, `<app-root>Loading...</app-root>`
3. Notice the syntax highlighting of any theme, how `app` is one color and `-root` is another color.

Screenshot: 

![screen shot 2016-10-11 at 11 07 31 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5883616/19280563/b218358a-8fa3-11e6-9358-36f1d921bae4.png)

data.title: Cmd-Q  on Mac is captured as a short-cut combination.
data.body:
VSCode doesn't close with standard Mac short-cut key combination.
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.0 (e52fb0bc87e6f5c8f144e172639891d8d8c9aa55, 2016-10-10T18:28:55.412Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.0.0
- Extensions: EditorConfig.EditorConfig-0.3.3, PeterJausovec.vscode-docker-0.0.6, TimonVS.ReactSnippetsStandard-1.0.3, TwentyChung.jsx-0.0.1, Tyriar.sort-lines-1.1.0, dbaeumer.vscode-eslint-1.0.7, eg2.tslint-0.5.39, hdg.live-html-previewer-0.0.1, hypnoes.word-count-0.1.1, joelday.docthis-0.3.4, michelemelluso.gitignore-1.0.1, ms-vscode.csharp-1.4.1, msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome-1.1.0, sidthesloth.html5-boilerplate-1.0.1, steve8708.Align-0.2.0, stevencl.addDocComments-0.0.8, vilicvane.es-quotes-0.2.4, wmaurer.change-case-0.4.1, wmaurer.join-lines-0.1.5, zgudino.editorconfig-vscode-snippet-0.1.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open vscode on a mac
2. Type Cmd-Q to close
3. Status bar notes that Cmd-Q was pressed. Waiting for second key of chord

Expected behaviour:
1. Open vscode on a mac
2. Type Cmd-Q to close
3. vscode should close

data.title: UX meeting agenda 12 October 2016
Add a setting to hide folder icons
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: 10.11.6

I use `vscode-icons` as my preferred icon set, but would prefer not to have the folder icons display in the explorer. I filed an issue with `vscode-icons` letting them know that the `vsicons.hideFolders` flag was no longer working and was told that this was a limitation of the api exposed by the latest version of VS Code (1.6.0).

Please could you provide an api to control the rendering of folder icons?

The issue I filed [can be found here](https://github.com/robertohuertasm/vscode-icons/issues/298#issuecomment-252939149).

data.title: Class and function dropdown boxes for code navigation
data.body: Requesting navigation feature that has been in Visual Studio (since before .NET, at least VS 6). For relevant languages, at the top of each editor window would be one or more dropdown boxes for navigating classes and functions. The easier implementation would be a single dropdown that contained function names in alphabetical order, allowing you to jump directly to it. If implementing more like Visual Studio, then two dropdown boxes, one for objects (classes, structs etc) and another dropdown for functions. Image of Visual Studio implementation: Side note: It seems the current methods available for navigation are either A) a lot of haphazard scrolling or B) use "Find" feature. The latter is not the right tool for the job because often a large amount of extraneous results are present, making it tedious. Thanks team! Loving VS Code

data.title: Horizontal scrollbar doesn’t shrink after the long line getting shortened

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.title: Highlight selection in a single long line is very slow
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an empty file;
2. Copy this line into your editor:

        
3. Select a single character ‘a’;
4. Observe the response time.

If it is not slow enough for you, you can try with more characters.

The response time is tolerable (but still a little long) if characters are distributed in different lines. Try this:

```
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa
```

This one is a lot faster than the previous one although they have the same number of ‘a’s.

Maybe the problem is with the algorithm. If the response time can’t be reduced, can you do the highlighting work in the background? I don’t want any thing to block my editing process. I don’t mind if some highlighting is delayed, but I can’t stand the UI being unresponsive.

Cannot Open Default Settings

data.title: formatOnSave make VSCode 1.6.0 going crazy on save
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 14393.222

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a JSON or HTML file (might apply to more files types)
2. Change something
3. Save and look at VSCode going crazy.

Quick video here : 
![formatonsavefreakoutlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2490360/19272814/089588f6-8f98-11e6-8164-26d29ad5cfe0.gif)

Then, if you try to close the file, it will ask if you want to save the file, if you discard the change, sometime it will replace the whole file content with `null`.  Haven't been able to reproduce this one, happened one time when I record the video.

There's no error in the dev console and I disabled all my extension prior of making the reproduction video.

data.title: Terminal focus key binding is not working correctly after update to 1.6
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add the following to your `keybindings.json`
2. Observe that it is broken

```
[{
    "key": "cmd+`",
    "command": "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
    "when": "editorTextFocus"
}]
```

Seems like a possible regression of #11714. Starting to get spooked by that update banner 😱

data.title: add setting for enabling breakpoints per language
data.body:
With support for languages that are transpiled to JavaScript, an end user needs a quick and simple way to enable breakpoints for new languages (without having to wait for a new extension to appear).

Since a new 'language' cannot be easily introduced as a user or workspace setting, I suggest to implement a pragmatic solution proposed by @isidorn: a setting `debugger.allowBreakpointsEverywhere` for enabling breakpoints for all (text) files.

data.title: Option to exclude items from Git branch checkout list

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.0-insider 
- OS Version: 10.12

When I click the "git branch" item at the left of the status bar, a popup appear with all the branches I might want to switch to, which is expected.

However, this menu lists all of our tags first, and we have dozens of tags on remote releases of our app.  It also lists the remote branches of the repo.

I always just want to switch between LOCAL branches I have already tracked.  This is the way the "git plus" extension for Atom works.  I find it hard to find the branch I am looking for in the list, even with type-ahead.  

I realize some people may want the current setup, so how about a prefs setting for "checkout shows local branches only" or something similar?  Or preference line items to exclude tags and/or remote branches?

data.title: IntelliSense design goes wrong with custom fonts.
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.6 - OS Version: macOS / El Capitan In 1.6 custom font-family & font-size also effects the intelliSense view. First of all thanks for that. However it has some problems. Padding is wrong and also the text is not in the aligns it has to be when you set light heights it goes even more wrong: If the be a good way of padding. A flex box vertical align or even the `vertical-align` of the CSS be used to center the text for good it would be so cool of you. P.S: I tried to fix this one but there was a node version conflict on my system. If you could give me advice on how to keep my node version to the latest while having a version for vscode development I can try to fix it myself. As always thanks for VS Code

data.title: Output channel highlighting is broken with removed text/x-code-output mimetype
Useless linking to libdbus-1.so.3?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

I'm packaging [vscode via OBS](https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:artem_sidorenko:testing/vscode) for myself. 

Today I noticed following warning [in the logs](https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/home:artem_sidorenko:testing/vscode/Ubuntu_15.10/x86_64):
`[  309s] dpkg-shlibdeps: warning: package could avoid a useless dependency if debian/vscode/opt/vscode/code was not linked against libdbus-1.so.3 (it uses none of the library's symbols)`

Steps to Reproduce:

``` bash
$ ldd /opt/vscode/code  | grep dbus
    libdbus-1.so.3 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdbus-1.so.3 (0x00007f9df1580000)
...
```

Is linking with libdbus required?

data.title: Console has empty lines/lines out of alignment

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 version 1607

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use console

As you may have gathered, I haven't got a set series of steps to reproduce this - I had a gulp watch running in the console, which is when the extra characters/lines appeared.

![vsc-console-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17826711/19269964/6191ff3a-8fb5-11e6-8931-6c7b8bda0d46.png)

I have the html for the the indented line, and the one above it, and as you can see there appears to be lines output when there is no console output, with some non-breaking spaces appearing before the contents of a line. I've never seen this in cmd, or in previous versions of the in-built terminal, and the task itself hasn't changed since the last update to vsc.

data.title: No longer able to debug typescript after VSCode update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.0 (e52fb0bc87e6f5c8f144e172639891d8d8c9aa55, 2016-10-10T18:37:40.189Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: christian-kohler.npm-intellisense-0.1.3, christian-kohler.path-intellisense-1.0.2, EditorConfig.EditorConfig-0.3.3, eg2.tslint-0.5.39, msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome-1.1.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Try to launch program using launch.json configuration
2. Get error: Cannot launch program 'XXXX\index.ts'; setting the 'outFiles' attribute might help
3. Setting the outFiles attribute has no effect

Config:

```
    {
        "name": "Launch",
        "type": "node",
        "request": "launch",
        "program": "${workspaceRoot}/src/index.ts",
        "stopOnEntry": false,
        "args": [],
        "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
        "preLaunchTask": null,
        "runtimeExecutable": null,
        "runtimeArgs": [
            "--nolazy"
        ],
        "env": {
            "NODE_ENV": "development"
        },
        "console": "internalConsole",
        "sourceMaps": true,
        "outFiles": [ "${workspaceRoot}/dist/**/*.js" ]
    },
```

data.title: "editor.snippetSuggestions": "top" Stopped working as intended
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

I have the following js snippet:

```
"Console.log": {
        "prefix": "cl",
        "body": ["console.log(${1:obj});$0"],
        "description": "Console log"
    },
```

There is a problem after last update. While the snippet shows on top in autocomplete, the term immediately after it (`class` in this case) is always selected by default. I have to use up arrow to select the snippet. Generally it just selects the most relevant autocomplete term not paying attention to snippets.
